subNodes.conversationText: root
Continue
Continue
Continue
Continue

[The town of Drawn Swords, a long day's march north of Corm Orp, is one of several lonely hamlets that dot the Western Heartlands of Faerun. It is most notable for the high crag on which it is built, and an inn known as the Sword and Dragon.]
Continue
[You arrived here with Vroman Horner, your friend and fellow adventurer, to meet his brother--a young mage named Manfred who wished to join you in your travels.]
Continue
[It has been three days since your arrival, and still there has been no word of him.]
Continue
He should have been here long ago. I suppose you're eager to leave, but Manfred is my brother, for better or worse.
I'm with you, Vroman.  We'll wait it out.

I did not really think you would give up. You've never failed me, very much unlike that slowcoach we're waiting for. Remember when you saved my life in Scornubel?--Well, since then I've kept you close. A true friend, you might say. Or at least a useful one.
Do I remember?  Of course.  We were at the Jaded Unicorn Inn.
[Jesting.] I have saved your life so many times that I can't rightly claim to remember that one very clearly.
Ha!  We were at that most notorious of dives, the Jaded Unicorn.  It was the night before we took on the guard contract with the Red Shields.
Continue

What a place!  I had just finished a glass of Halfling's Head, when out came a monstrous half-orc, besotted and bleary-eyed, with two aces of spades in his hands.  He claimed I cheated him, and put his dagger to my jugular!
Continue
No one even saw you strike, you were so swift.  One hit, and down he went.  Just don't do the same thing to Manfred once he gets here.
That's not quite how I remember it, Vroman--and I believe you did cheat him, didn't you?
Of course!  But back to present concerns--
Continue
I know it's come up before, but once Manfred gets here, where do you think we should head?  I hear work's thin in Neverwinter.  Waterdeep, perhaps?
Continue
[The door of the Sword and Dragon slams, and a woman, fair of complexion and clad in highly polished, decorative mail, enters. The inn quiets considerably.]
Continue
I am looking for a man named Vroman Horner.  Is he here?
Continue
I am Vroman Horner.
Continue
[The woman walks briskly to Vroman with sure step, as if all eyes in the inn were not watching her.]
Continue
Greetings, Vroman.  I am Ianth, Knight of the Ruby Rose and devoted protector of the town of Drawn Swords.
Continue
[At the word "protector," a few of the people in the inn begin to murmur. A look from Ianth immediately quiets them.]
Continue

There is no easy way to say this.  Your brother Manfred is dead, killed by brigands on his way through Northdark Wood.  I reached him too late, but was in time to learn that he was supposed to meet you here.
Continue
Alas!  I knew Tymora would turn her back on that fool one of these days.  Is he really dead?
Continue

Yes, though you will be glad to know that I have brought his body to town.  It rests at the top of the crag, where Brother Anselm watches over it.  Again, I am sorry for your loss, but now I must leave you to your grief.
You owe us more of an explanation than this.  Tell us all you know.
Owe you, stranger?  I think not.  In truth, it was foolish for that man to walk such a dangerous road alone; I risked life and limb myself to bring him here.
Continue
If you wish to know more, seek me inside Swordskeep.  I have business to speak of with Hamfast.  Farewell.
Continue
I am at a loss for words, <FirstName>.  This is one blow I can't dodge.  Damn.
Continue

Hey there, friend.  I couldn't help but overhear what Mistress Ianth was telling you.  Hard luck, hard luck.  You might not think old Danmar much in the way of sympathy, but I've got a flask of elverquisst who's very kind.  Take it with my best wishes.
Continue
Tymora bless you, Danmar.
Vroman, I would understand if you needed some time by yourself.  I know I would.
No, friend, I am not one to keep a cup of bitters to myself.  The poison's sweeter if shared.
Continue
The bearer of the bad news was strange, wasn't she?  I've never met a Sune-worshipper like her before.
Continue

[The innkeeper interjects once more.] Aye, Ianth's not your typical pleasure-seeking, warm-hearted follower of the goddess of love. She does good by the town, but the locals mistrust her. Who's ever heard of an icy Sunite?
[Nod.] Interesting. Are you ready, Vroman?
Yes.  Let us view the body.  By the gods, this is not how I'd intended to spend the afternoon.  Lead on.
[End Dialog.]
Yes.  Let us view the body.  By the gods, this is not how I'd intended to spend the afternoon.  Lead on.
[End Dialog.]
Yes.  Let us view the body.  By the gods, this is not how I'd intended to spend the afternoon.  Lead on.
[End Dialog.]
Yes.  Let us view the body.  By the gods, this is not how I'd intended to spend the afternoon.  Lead on.
[End Dialog.]
Indeed.  Well, Vroman, are you prepared for this?  You can take your time, you know.
We should certainly speak to her after we have viewed the body.  She might be able to direct us to your brother's murderers.
Vroman, I am sorry.  Is there anything I can do for you?
There is not really much you can do.  Death is just that way--most of the time.  Alas.
Continue
It would be good for you to see the body, Vroman, and to pay your last respects to Manfred.  Let us go.
Of course. Before we go, though, the bearer of bad news was strange, wasn't she?  I've never met a Sune-worshipper like her before.
Continue
I will leave you to your suffering.
Milady, this is terrible news.  Surely you will not leave without telling Vroman how exactly this all transpired.
Wait!  Do not leave just yet!
Farewell, then.
You exaggerate slightly, Vroman, but are right in the main.
You remember things with remarkable clarity, Vroman.
But then you whistled like a skylark, distracting him enough for me to get away, and for you to push your knife through his belly.
But you turned and smote him in the name of <Deity> before he could even think his next thought.

But then he suddenly found himself facing a wolf that appeared out of nowhere, growling at him from the top of the bar.  Your doing, of course.  I'll never forget the look he had on his face as it mauled him.
But you melted out of the shadows and put your knife through his jugular. He was whistling in the Hells before he even hit the floor.
But suddenly there was a flash, and the smell of fire and brimstone, and down went the half-orc, slain by your magic.  Gods, I wish you were always so quick with it.
Like you, Vroman, I never tire of hearing tales of my heroics.
Manfred will show up.  He must have misjudged how long the road from Berdusk to Drawn Swords really is.
True.  Manfred was never known for his fine judgment.
Continue
No, we should not even think of leaving, Vroman.  Kin is kin.
Yes--for better or worse, as I said.
Continue
What, you think I have something better to do than wait around in this backwater?
I'm glad we are of the same mind.  I just wish he would hurry.
Continue
I am growing impatient.

I know. You're not one to put up with too much tarrying. But you've never failed me, very much unlike that slowcoach we're waiting for. Remember when you saved my life in that nasty bar brawl?--Well, since then I've kept you close. A true friend, you might say. Or at least a useful one.
